hasDefinedTerm.description: A type of material or fuel that ignites spontaneously when it comes into contact with an oxidizer. Hypergolic materials are commonly used in rocket propulsion but pose significant fire risks due to their reactive nature.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Hyperthermia
hasDefinedTerm.description: An abnormally high body temperature that can result from exposure to excessive heat, such as during a fire. Hyperthermia is a medical emergency that can lead to heat exhaustion, heat stroke, and severe health complications.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Hypoxia
hasDefinedTerm.description: A condition in which the body or a region of the body is deprived of adequate oxygen supply. Hypoxia can occur during a fire due to high levels of smoke or reduced oxygen in the environment and poses significant risks to both occupants and responders.

hasDefinedTerm.name: IAAI
hasDefinedTerm.description: The International Association of Arson Investigators, an organization that provides training, certification, and resources for professionals involved in fire investigation. The IAAI sets standards for conducting thorough and accurate fire investigations.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Ignitible Liquid Detection Canines
hasDefinedTerm.description: Specially trained dogs used to detect the presence of ignitable liquids at fire scenes. These canines assist investigators in locating potential accelerants that may indicate arson.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Ignition
hasDefinedTerm.description: The process of starting a fire by applying sufficient heat to a fuel source. Ignition can be natural, accidental, or intentional and is a critical focus in fire investigations.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Ignition Area
hasDefinedTerm.description: The specific location where a fire first started. Determining the ignition area is essential for understanding the fire's cause and origin.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Ignition Energy
hasDefinedTerm.description: The minimum amount of energy required to initiate combustion in a particular material. Ignition energy varies by material and environmental conditions, and understanding it helps assess fire risk.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Ignition Method
hasDefinedTerm.description: The specific way in which a fire is started, such as using an open flame, electrical spark, or chemical reaction. Identifying the ignition method helps fire investigators determine whether a fire was accidental or intentional.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Ignition Probability
hasDefinedTerm.description: The likelihood that a fire will start based on the conditions of fuel, heat, and oxygen availability. Ignition probability is used in fire risk assessments to predict potential fire outbreaks.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Ignition Sources
hasDefinedTerm.description: Objects or actions that can provide the heat necessary for ignition, such as matches, lighters, electrical faults, or friction. Identifying ignition sources is crucial in fire investigations to determine fire causes.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Ignition Switch
hasDefinedTerm.description: A component in vehicles and machinery that starts the engine or system. Faulty ignition switches can be a source of electrical fires, especially if they create a spark or short circuit.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Ignition Temperature
hasDefinedTerm.description: The minimum temperature at which a material can spontaneously ignite without an external flame. Ignition temperatures are key to understanding the fire risks of different materials.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Ignition Time
hasDefinedTerm.description: The amount of time required for a material to ignite when exposed to heat. This time can vary based on the material type, heat source, and environmental conditions.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Ignition, Spontaneous
hasDefinedTerm.description: The process by which a material catches fire without an external flame or spark, often due to a chemical reaction, heat buildup, or decomposition. Spontaneous ignition poses risks in storage of materials like oily rags and certain chemicals.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Immiscible
hasDefinedTerm.description: The property of two substances that do not mix or blend uniformly, such as oil and water. Understanding immiscibility is important when considering fire suppression tactics involving liquids.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Impact Resistance
hasDefinedTerm.description: The ability of a material to withstand mechanical force without cracking or breaking. Materials with high impact resistance are often used in fire-resistant building construction to maintain structural integrity during a fire.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Impedance
hasDefinedTerm.description: The resistance of an electrical circuit to the flow of alternating current (AC), which can affect heat generation in electrical systems. High impedance can lead to overheating and potential fire hazards.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Incendiary
hasDefinedTerm.description: A type of fire that is intentionally set with the intent to cause damage or harm. Incendiary fires are often associated with arson and require investigation to identify the cause and perpetrator.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Incendiary Fire
hasDefinedTerm.description: A fire that has been deliberately ignited to cause destruction or damage. Such fires are typically illegal and are investigated as acts of arson.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Incident
hasDefinedTerm.description: An event or occurrence that requires emergency response, such as a fire, explosion, or accident. Incidents can range in severity from minor to catastrophic and may involve multiple agencies for resolution.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Incident Action Plan (IAP)
hasDefinedTerm.description: A formal document outlining the strategy, tactics, and resources needed to manage and resolve an incident. The IAP is used in firefighting and emergency management to coordinate response efforts effectively.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Incident Command Post (ICP)
hasDefinedTerm.description: The on-site location where the incident commander and key staff coordinate and manage emergency response efforts. The ICP is the central point for communication and decision-making during an incident.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Incident Command System (ICS)
hasDefinedTerm.description: A standardized framework used to manage emergency response operations, ensuring clear communication and organization. ICS allows multiple agencies to work together efficiently during complex incidents like large-scale fires.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Incident Commander
hasDefinedTerm.description: The individual responsible for overseeing all operations at the scene of an emergency. The incident commander leads the strategic and tactical response and ensures the safety of personnel and the public.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Incident Management Team
hasDefinedTerm.description: A group of trained personnel that oversees the coordination and management of large or complex incidents, such as wildfires or natural disasters. Teams can be local, regional, or national in scope.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Incident Objectives
hasDefinedTerm.description: The specific goals set for managing an incident, such as containment, suppression, and protecting life and property. Incident objectives guide the actions of response teams and ensure a unified approach.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Incident Reporting
hasDefinedTerm.description: The process of documenting the details and response to an emergency incident. Incident reports provide a record for analysis, lessons learned, and potential legal or insurance purposes.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Incipient Phase
hasDefinedTerm.description: The initial stage of a fire, characterized by low heat and limited flame spread. Early detection and response during the incipient phase can prevent a fire from growing out of control.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Inductive Reasoning
hasDefinedTerm.description: A logical approach used to develop general conclusions based on specific observations and evidence. In fire investigations, inductive reasoning helps form hypotheses about the cause of a fire based on the available data.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Inert
hasDefinedTerm.description: A substance that does not react chemically under normal conditions. Inert gases, like nitrogen, are often used in fire suppression systems to displace oxygen and smother a fire.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Infrared Detection
hasDefinedTerm.description: The use of infrared technology to detect heat sources and hot spots that are not visible to the naked eye. Infrared cameras and sensors are used in firefighting and fire investigations to monitor fire activity and locate hidden flames.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Initial Attack
hasDefinedTerm.description: The first efforts made by firefighters and response teams to control and suppress a fire when it is still small and manageable. Effective initial attacks can prevent fires from escalating into larger incidents.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Insurance
hasDefinedTerm.description: A financial product that provides compensation for losses or damage caused by covered events, such as fire. Property and fire insurance help policyholders recover after incidents and mitigate financial risks.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Insurance Adjuster
hasDefinedTerm.description: A professional responsible for assessing and evaluating insurance claims, including those related to fire damage. Adjusters determine the extent of the damage and the compensation amount for the insured party.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Insurance Agent
hasDefinedTerm.description: A representative who sells insurance policies to customers and helps them understand coverage options. Agents may assist clients in choosing policies that protect against fire and other risks.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Insurance Broker
hasDefinedTerm.description: An intermediary who represents clients to help them find the best insurance policies for their needs, including coverage for fire protection. Brokers work independently from insurance companies to find suitable policies.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Insurance Carrier
hasDefinedTerm.description: The company or organization that provides insurance coverage and pays out claims. Insurance carriers underwrite policies and assess risks, including those related to fire damage.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Insurance Claims
hasDefinedTerm.description: Requests made by policyholders to their insurance company for compensation or coverage following a loss or damage, such as from a fire. Claims must be supported with documentation and evidence of the incident.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Insurance Contract
hasDefinedTerm.description: A legal agreement between an insurer and an insured party outlining the terms, coverage, and conditions of the insurance policy. This contract specifies what is covered, such as fire damage, and the obligations of both parties.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Insurance Fraud
hasDefinedTerm.description: The act of intentionally deceiving an insurance company to receive compensation or benefits unlawfully. Insurance fraud can involve staged fires or false claims of fire damage.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Insurance Money
hasDefinedTerm.description: The funds provided by an insurance company to a policyholder as compensation for a covered loss or damage, such as fire-related destruction of property.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Insurance Policy
hasDefinedTerm.description: A document detailing the terms, conditions, and coverage of an insurance agreement. Fire insurance policies outline what fire-related damages are covered and under what circumstances.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Insure
hasDefinedTerm.description: To provide financial protection against potential losses or damages by purchasing an insurance policy. Many individuals and businesses insure properties to safeguard against fire damage.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Insured
hasDefinedTerm.description: The person or entity that holds an insurance policy and is protected under the terms of that policy. The insured party is eligible for compensation in the event of fire damage if it falls within the policy's coverage.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Insurer
hasDefinedTerm.description: The company or organization that provides insurance coverage and pays out claims when a covered event, such as a fire, occurs. Insurers assess risk and set premiums for policies.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Intent
hasDefinedTerm.description: The purpose or mindset behind an action, particularly when determining whether a fire was set intentionally or by accident. In arson cases, proving intent is key to legal proceedings.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Interested Party
hasDefinedTerm.description: Any individual or organization with a vested interest in the outcome of a fire investigation or insurance claim. This can include property owners, insurers, and other stakeholders.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Internal Resistance
hasDefinedTerm.description: The opposition to the flow of electric current within a battery or electrical system, which generates heat. High internal resistance can lead to overheating and potential fire risks.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Investigative Lead
hasDefinedTerm.description: A piece of information or evidence that guides a fire investigator towards a potential cause or suspect. Leads can come from witnesses, physical evidence, or data analysis.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Investigative Team
hasDefinedTerm.description: A group of professionals who collaborate on a fire investigation to determine the cause, origin, and contributing factors. The team may include fire investigators, forensic experts, and law enforcement officers.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Isochar
hasDefinedTerm.description: A line or marking that indicates areas of equal burn intensity on a fire-damaged surface. Isochar mapping helps investigators understand the progression and severity of a fire.

hasDefinedTerm.name: I-Zone
hasDefinedTerm.description: A term used to describe the interface zone where urban development meets wildland areas, creating a higher risk for wildfires that can impact homes and infrastructure.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Job Hazard Analysis
hasDefinedTerm.description: A process of identifying potential hazards associated with specific jobs or tasks, including fire risks. This analysis helps in creating safer work practices and emergency response plans.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Joule
hasDefinedTerm.description: A unit of energy in the International System of Units (SI). In fire investigations, joules may be used to measure the energy released during combustion or electrical discharge.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Jump Spot
hasDefinedTerm.description: A designated location where smokejumpers (firefighters trained to parachute into remote areas) can safely land to begin firefighting operations.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Jump Suit
hasDefinedTerm.description: A specialized suit worn by smokejumpers that provides protection against flames, abrasion, and impact during their descent and initial firefighting efforts.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Keech Byram Drought Index (KBDI)
hasDefinedTerm.description: An index used to measure the dryness of soil and vegetation, indicating the potential for fire ignition and spread. Higher KBDI values suggest greater fire risk due to dry conditions.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Kilowatt
hasDefinedTerm.description: A unit of power equal to 1,000 watts, commonly used to measure the output of electrical devices and energy release during fires. Kilowatt ratings help assess the energy demands and potential heat generation in electrical systems.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Kindling
hasDefinedTerm.description: Small, dry twigs or pieces of wood that ignite easily and are used to start a fire. Kindling plays an essential role in the initial phase of fire ignition.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Kindling Temperature
hasDefinedTerm.description: The minimum temperature required for a material to ignite and sustain combustion without an external flame. Knowing the kindling temperature of materials helps assess fire risk and prevention strategies.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Kinetic
hasDefinedTerm.description: Related to motion or movement. In fire dynamics, kinetic energy contributes to the movement of gases, flames, and embers, affecting fire spread and behavior.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Kinetic Theory
hasDefinedTerm.description: A theory that explains the behavior of particles in matter, especially gases, and their response to heat. In fire science, kinetic theory helps describe how heat energy causes molecules to move and ignite.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Kinetics
hasDefinedTerm.description: The study of the rate at which chemical reactions occur, including combustion reactions in fires. Kinetics helps understand the speed of ignition and the progression of a fire.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Knock Down
hasDefinedTerm.description: The initial phase of fire suppression when water or fire retardants are applied to reduce flames and control the fire’s intensity. "Knock down" helps prevent further spread and allows firefighters to move into the overhaul phase.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Ladder Fuels
hasDefinedTerm.description: Vegetation or materials that allow a fire to climb from the forest floor up to the canopy. Ladder fuels contribute to the vertical spread of a fire, making it more difficult to control.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Laminar Flow
hasDefinedTerm.description: A smooth, uninterrupted flow of air or fluid, where particles move in parallel layers with minimal mixing. In fire science, understanding laminar flow helps predict smoke movement and fire spread in controlled environments.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Large Fire
hasDefinedTerm.description: A fire that exceeds the capabilities of initial attack resources and requires significant additional firefighting efforts and coordination. Large fires can spread rapidly and pose significant risks to life and property.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Latent Heat
hasDefinedTerm.description: The amount of heat energy absorbed or released during a phase change of a substance, such as water turning into steam, without changing temperature. In fire behavior, latent heat impacts the ignition and spread of flames.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Latent Heat of Vaporization
hasDefinedTerm.description: The amount of energy required for a liquid to convert into a vapor without a temperature increase. This property is important for understanding the heat transfer in fires involving water-based suppression.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Lateral Fire
hasDefinedTerm.description: The horizontal spread of fire along the ground or across a landscape. Lateral fire spread is influenced by wind, fuel type, and topography and is a key factor in fire containment strategies.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Layering
hasDefinedTerm.description: The accumulation of different types of fuels in distinct layers, such as grasses, brush, and tree limbs. Layering affects fire intensity, spread, and the difficulty of suppression.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Lead Plane
hasDefinedTerm.description: An aircraft that flies ahead of air tankers during aerial firefighting operations to mark the target area for water or retardant drops. The lead plane ensures accuracy and safety in aerial drops.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Lifesaving Appliances
hasDefinedTerm.description: Equipment designed to protect and save lives during fire emergencies, such as fire extinguishers, fire blankets, and personal protective equipment (PPE). Lifesaving appliances are essential for occupant and firefighter safety.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Light Fuels
hasDefinedTerm.description: Fine, dry materials such as grass, leaves, and needles that ignite quickly and burn with high intensity. Light fuels contribute to the rapid spread of surface fires.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Light Petroleum Distillate
hasDefinedTerm.description: A category of petroleum products that are less dense and have lower boiling points, such as gasoline and kerosene. These distillates are highly flammable and are analyzed in fire investigations as potential accelerants.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Lightning Activity Level (LAL)
hasDefinedTerm.description: A scale used to measure lightning activity, which indicates the potential for fire ignition from lightning strikes. Higher LAL values correlate with increased fire risk.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Line of Demarcation
hasDefinedTerm.description: A clear boundary indicating the division between burned and unburned areas at a fire scene. This line helps investigators determine the fire's progress and potential origin.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Line Scout
hasDefinedTerm.description: A firefighter or team member responsible for locating and marking potential fire lines in wildfire management. Line scouts identify areas where control lines can be established to contain the fire.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Lines of Demarcation
hasDefinedTerm.description: Multiple boundaries used to identify different stages of fire spread or areas affected by varying levels of fire intensity. These lines aid in mapping fire behavior and planning suppression tactics.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Lithium Plating
hasDefinedTerm.description: The deposition of lithium metal on a battery’s anode, which can occur during rapid charging or low-temperature charging. Lithium plating increases the risk of internal short circuits and fires.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Lithium-ion Battery
hasDefinedTerm.description: A type of rechargeable battery commonly used in electronic devices and electric vehicles. Lithium-ion batteries can pose fire risks if damaged or overheated due to thermal runaway and potential ignition.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Litter
hasDefinedTerm.description: Loose, dead plant material such as leaves, twigs, and bark on the forest floor. Litter acts as a surface fuel, contributing to the ignition and spread of wildfires.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Live Fuels
hasDefinedTerm.description: Vegetation that still has moisture content and is capable of burning, though less easily than dead fuels. Live fuels can still contribute to fire spread under dry or extreme conditions.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Lividity
hasDefinedTerm.description: The post-mortem settling of blood in the body that results in a purplish discoloration of the skin. In fire investigations involving fatalities, lividity can help determine the time and position of death.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Low Explosive
hasDefinedTerm.description: A type of explosive that deflagrates (burns rapidly) rather than detonates. Low explosives are typically used in propellants and fireworks and can pose fire risks under certain conditions.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Low Explosive vs Low Order Explosion
hasDefinedTerm.description: A comparison between the deflagration of low explosives and a low order explosion, which is characterized by incomplete combustion and minimal damage compared to a high order explosion.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Lower Flammable Limit
hasDefinedTerm.description: The lowest concentration of a flammable vapor or gas in the air that can ignite. Concentrations below this limit are too "lean" to sustain combustion.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Low-Ignition Construction
hasDefinedTerm.description: Building design and materials that are resistant to ignition and reduce the spread of fire. This type of construction is used in fire-prone areas to enhance safety and resilience.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Low-Ignition Landscaping
hasDefinedTerm.description: Landscaping practices that use fire-resistant plants and non-combustible materials to create defensible space around structures. This strategy helps prevent the spread of wildfire to buildings.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Low-Order Damage
hasDefinedTerm.description: Damage resulting from an explosion that is less severe, characterized by slower combustion and minimal shock wave impact. This type of damage may indicate a low explosive or incomplete detonation.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Malice
hasDefinedTerm.description: The intention to commit a harmful or unlawful act. In the context of fire investigations, proving malice is crucial in cases of arson where intent must be established for prosecution.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Manufacturing Facility
hasDefinedTerm.description: A site where goods are produced and may involve the use of flammable or hazardous materials. Fires at manufacturing facilities can be particularly dangerous due to the presence of volatile substances.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Marine Engine Fire
hasDefinedTerm.description: A fire that originates in the engine compartment of a boat or ship, often due to fuel leaks, electrical malfunctions, or overheating. Marine engine fires require specialized firefighting techniques due to confined spaces and potential fuel hazards.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Marine Fire Suppression
hasDefinedTerm.description: Techniques and systems used to control and extinguish fires on boats, ships, and other marine vessels. Marine fire suppression may involve water, foam, or specialized extinguishing agents.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Marine Firefighting
hasDefinedTerm.description: The specialized practice of combating fires on vessels, ports, and waterfronts. This type of firefighting requires knowledge of ship structure, onboard fire hazards, and the use of marine-specific equipment.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Marine Insurance Claims
hasDefinedTerm.description: Insurance claims related to damages or losses from fires that occur on ships or at sea. These claims often involve complex assessments due to the unique challenges of marine fires.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Marine Safety Protocols
hasDefinedTerm.description: Procedures and guidelines designed to prevent and manage fires and other emergencies on marine vessels. These protocols include regular inspections, fire drills, and the maintenance of fire suppression systems.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Material First Ignited
hasDefinedTerm.description: The initial material that catches fire and sustains combustion at the start of a fire incident. Identifying this material helps investigators pinpoint the fire's origin and potential ignition sources.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Mechanical Failure
hasDefinedTerm.description: The malfunction or breakdown of machinery or equipment that can lead to overheating, sparking, or other conditions conducive to fire. Mechanical failure is a common cause of industrial and vehicle fires.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Medium Petroleum Distillate
hasDefinedTerm.description: A type of petroleum product that falls between light and heavy distillates, including substances such as kerosene and diesel fuel. Medium distillates can be flammable and are significant in fire investigations involving accelerants.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Melting Point
hasDefinedTerm.description: The temperature at which a solid becomes a liquid. In fire investigations, understanding the melting point of materials helps determine the temperature and heat exposure at the scene.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Micro-Remote Environmental Monitoring System (Mirco-REMS)
hasDefinedTerm.description: A system that uses remote sensors to monitor environmental conditions, such as temperature, humidity, and wind, which can impact fire behavior. Micro-REMS data helps fire managers make informed decisions during wildfire incidents.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Mineral Soil
hasDefinedTerm.description: Soil composed mostly of inorganic materials, which is less combustible than organic soil layers like duff. Mineral soil can act as a natural firebreak in wildland fire management.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Minimum Explosible Concentration (MEC)
hasDefinedTerm.description: The lowest concentration of combustible dust or gas in the air that can ignite and cause an explosion. MEC is an important parameter for assessing fire risks in industrial settings.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Minimum Ignition Energy (MIE)
hasDefinedTerm.description: The least amount of energy needed to ignite a specific fuel-air mixture. Understanding MIE helps in assessing the likelihood of ignition under various conditions.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Miscibility
hasDefinedTerm.description: The ability of two substances to mix together in any proportion without separating. Miscibility is significant in fire scenarios involving liquid fuels and suppressants.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Misdemeanor
hasDefinedTerm.description: A criminal offense that is less severe than a felony but still punishable by fines, community service, or imprisonment. In fire cases, misdemeanors can include violations of fire safety codes or negligent acts leading to fire incidents.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Mitigation
hasDefinedTerm.description: Actions taken to reduce the severity or likelihood of a fire, such as clearing vegetation, installing firebreaks, or using fire-resistant building materials. Mitigation is essential in fire prevention and risk management.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Mobilization
hasDefinedTerm.description: The process of deploying firefighting resources and personnel to respond to a fire incident. Mobilization ensures that the appropriate equipment and responders are on-site promptly to combat a fire.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Modular Airborne Firefighting System (MAFFS)
hasDefinedTerm.description: A portable system installed in military aircraft for aerial firefighting. MAFFS units allow planes to drop water or fire retardant over wildfires to assist ground crews.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Modus Operandi
hasDefinedTerm.description: A term referring to the typical method or pattern of behavior associated with an individual or event. In fire investigations, understanding an arsonist’s modus operandi can help identify repeat offenders and predict future incidents.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Mop-up
hasDefinedTerm.description: The process of extinguishing any remaining flames, embers, or hotspots after the main fire has been suppressed. Mop-up prevents rekindling and ensures the fire is fully contained.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Motive
hasDefinedTerm.description: The reason behind an action, especially in cases of intentional fire-setting or arson. Establishing motive is essential in legal proceedings to prove intent and link suspects to the crime.

hasDefinedTerm.name: MOU
hasDefinedTerm.description: An agreement between organizations or agencies outlining cooperative actions and responsibilities, such as sharing resources or coordinating responses during fire incidents.

hasDefinedTerm.name: MOU (Memorandum of Understanding)
hasDefinedTerm.description: An agreement between organizations or agencies outlining cooperative actions and responsibilities, such as sharing resources or coordinating responses during fire incidents.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Multi-Agency Coordination (MAC)
hasDefinedTerm.description: A system that facilitates collaboration between different agencies responding to a fire or emergency. MAC ensures efficient communication, resource sharing, and strategic alignment in complex incidents.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Mutual Aid Agreement
hasDefinedTerm.description: An arrangement between emergency response agencies to provide assistance and resources during incidents that exceed the capacity of a single organization. These agreements are crucial for large-scale firefighting efforts.

hasDefinedTerm.name: NAFI
hasDefinedTerm.description: The National Association of Fire Investigators, a professional organization dedicated to promoting fire investigation and prevention through education, certification, and research.

hasDefinedTerm.name: NAFI Resources
hasDefinedTerm.description: Educational materials, certification programs, and training offered by the National Association of Fire Investigators (NAFI) to support fire investigators in enhancing their skills and knowledge.

hasDefinedTerm.name: National Environmental Policy Act (NEPA)
hasDefinedTerm.description: A U.S. law requiring federal agencies to assess the environmental effects of their proposed actions, including those related to fire management and prevention. NEPA ensures that fire mitigation strategies do not adversely impact the environment.

hasDefinedTerm.name: National Fire Academy
hasDefinedTerm.description: An institution that provides training and education for fire and emergency services personnel. The National Fire Academy offers courses on fire prevention, investigation, and management.

hasDefinedTerm.name: National Fire Danger Rating System
hasDefinedTerm.description: A system used to evaluate and communicate the risk of wildfires in a specific area. The system considers factors such as fuel moisture, temperature, wind speed, and humidity to assess fire potential.

hasDefinedTerm.name: National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST)
hasDefinedTerm.description: A U.S. federal agency that conducts research and sets standards in various fields, including fire safety. NIST contributes to the development of fire investigation techniques and fire protection standards.

hasDefinedTerm.name: National Wildfire Coordinating Group
hasDefinedTerm.description: An interagency group that coordinates national wildfire response and sets standards for training and procedures in wildfire management. It ensures that different firefighting agencies work cohesively.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Natural Barrier
hasDefinedTerm.description: A landscape feature, such as a river, rocky area, or road, that helps prevent or slow the spread of a fire. Natural barriers are often used in fire management plans to create containment lines.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Negligence
hasDefinedTerm.description: The failure to take reasonable precautions to prevent fire hazards, which can result in unintended fires. Legal cases involving fire may cite negligence if proper safety measures were not followed.

hasDefinedTerm.name: NFPA
hasDefinedTerm.description: The National Fire Protection Association, an international organization that develops and publishes fire safety codes and standards. NFPA guidelines are widely used to enhance fire prevention and safety practices.

hasDefinedTerm.name: NFPA 1033
hasDefinedTerm.description: The standard outlining the professional qualifications for fire investigators. NFPA 1033 specifies the knowledge and skills required to conduct thorough and effective fire investigations.

hasDefinedTerm.name: NFPA 1321
hasDefinedTerm.description: A standard that addresses the management and operation of fire protection services, including fire department administration, training, and safety protocols.

hasDefinedTerm.name: NFPA 302 Standards
hasDefinedTerm.description: Specific NFPA standards related to fire safety practices for boats and marine vessels. These standards outline best practices for preventing and responding to fires on watercraft.

hasDefinedTerm.name: NFPA 921
hasDefinedTerm.description: A comprehensive guide for fire and explosion investigations published by the National Fire Protection Association. NFPA 921 is used by fire investigators to standardize investigative techniques and methodologies.

hasDefinedTerm.name: NFPA 921 Standards
hasDefinedTerm.description: The established criteria outlined in NFPA 921 that guide fire investigators in examining and determining the cause of fires and explosions.

hasDefinedTerm.name: NFPA Codes
hasDefinedTerm.description: A set of safety standards and regulations developed by the National Fire Protection Association to guide fire safety practices. These codes cover areas such as building design, fire prevention, and firefighting procedures.

hasDefinedTerm.name: NFPA Standards
hasDefinedTerm.description: The established safety and fire prevention protocols published by the National Fire Protection Association. NFPA standards are used globally to ensure fire safety in various industries and settings.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Nomex
hasDefinedTerm.description: A flame-resistant material used in protective clothing for firefighters and other emergency personnel. Nomex is known for its durability and ability to withstand high temperatures, providing critical protection in fire situations.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Noncombustible
hasDefinedTerm.description: A term used to describe materials that do not ignite or burn easily. Noncombustible materials are essential in fire-resistant construction and safety designs.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Noncombustible Material
hasDefinedTerm.description: A type of material that does not burn or contribute to fire spread. Examples include certain metals, bricks, and treated materials used in building construction for added safety.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Nonflammable
hasDefinedTerm.description: Substances or materials that do not catch fire easily under normal conditions. Nonflammable materials are important for minimizing fire risk in construction and manufacturing.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Non-Scene Data
hasDefinedTerm.description: Information and evidence collected that is not directly from the fire scene but supports the investigation, such as surveillance footage, witness statements, and historical weather data. Non-scene data helps provide context for understanding the fire.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Non-Waiver Agreement
hasDefinedTerm.description: A legal document in which an insurance company and the insured party agree that any actions taken during an investigation do not waive rights or obligations under the insurance policy. This is important in fire investigations to ensure all parties retain their legal positions.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Normal Fire Season
hasDefinedTerm.description: The period of the year when wildfires are most likely to occur based on historical weather patterns, vegetation conditions, and fire activity. Understanding the normal fire season helps with preparedness and resource allocation.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Odometer
hasDefinedTerm.description: An instrument used to measure the distance traveled by a vehicle. In fire investigations involving vehicles, the odometer reading can provide clues about usage prior to a fire event.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Ohm, Ohm’s Law
hasDefinedTerm.description: A fundamental principle in electrical engineering that states the relationship between voltage, current, and resistance in an electrical circuit: V=I×RV = I \times RV=I×R (voltage equals current times resistance). Understanding Ohm’s Law is important in determining electrical causes of fires.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Open Burning
hasDefinedTerm.description: The act of burning materials, such as yard waste or refuse, in an open space without a contained structure or fire safety measures. Open burning can lead to unintentional fires if not controlled properly.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Open Flame
hasDefinedTerm.description: A visible flame from a source such as a candle, match, or torch. Open flames can easily ignite combustible materials and are a common ignition source in fire incidents.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Operational Period
hasDefinedTerm.description: The specific time frame during which firefighting activities or emergency operations are planned and executed. Operational periods are typically 12 to 24 hours and include objectives and resource assignments.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Operations Branch Director
hasDefinedTerm.description: A leader within the Incident Command System responsible for overseeing and managing all tactical operations at a fire or emergency scene. The Operations Branch Director ensures that firefighting and suppression efforts align with incident objectives.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Origin
hasDefinedTerm.description: The specific location where a fire began. Determining the origin is a critical step in fire investigations to identify potential ignition sources and causes.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Origin & Cause
hasDefinedTerm.description: The process of determining where and how a fire started. This is a foundational aspect of fire investigation that involves analyzing evidence, fire patterns, and potential ignition sources.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Overcharging
hasDefinedTerm.description: The process of charging a battery beyond its capacity, which can cause overheating, degradation, and potential ignition. Overcharging is a significant risk in lithium-ion batteries and other rechargeable energy sources.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Overcurrent
hasDefinedTerm.description: An electrical condition where current exceeds the designed limit of a circuit, leading to overheating and potential fire risks. Overcurrent protection devices, such as circuit breakers, are used to prevent this condition.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Overcurrent and Overload
hasDefinedTerm.description: Terms describing conditions where an electrical system experiences more current than it can safely handle. This can lead to overheating, damaged wiring, and increased fire risk.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Overhaul
hasDefinedTerm.description: The process of searching for and extinguishing any remaining hot spots or smoldering materials after the main fire has been suppressed. Overhaul prevents rekindling and ensures the fire is fully extinguished.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Overhead
hasDefinedTerm.description: Personnel who provide support and leadership in a fire incident, including supervisors, coordinators, and command staff. Overhead staff play a crucial role in organizing and managing firefighting operations.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Overheating Equipment
hasDefinedTerm.description: Machinery or appliances that generate excessive heat due to malfunction, wear, or improper use. Overheated equipment is a common ignition source for fires.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Overheating Protection
hasDefinedTerm.description: Safety features and devices that prevent equipment from reaching temperatures that could cause a fire. These include thermostats, circuit breakers, and thermal cutoffs.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Overload
hasDefinedTerm.description: A condition where electrical demand exceeds the system's capacity, causing overheating and potential fire hazards. Overloaded circuits can be prevented by using properly rated electrical equipment and distribution.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Overloaded Circuits
hasDefinedTerm.description: Electrical circuits that carry more current than they are designed to handle, leading to overheating and potential ignition of surrounding materials. This is a common cause of electrical fires in homes and businesses.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Overstory
hasDefinedTerm.description: The upper layer of vegetation in a forest, consisting of the tallest trees. The overstory can influence fire behavior by providing ladder fuels that allow a fire to climb from the ground to the canopy.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Oxidation
hasDefinedTerm.description: A chemical reaction in which a substance combines with oxygen, often releasing energy in the form of heat and light. Oxidation is a fundamental process in combustion and fire behavior.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Oxide
hasDefinedTerm.description: A compound formed when an element combines with oxygen. Metal oxides, such as iron oxide (rust), can be analyzed in fire investigations to determine exposure to heat and the progression of a fire.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Oxides
hasDefinedTerm.description: Various compounds made by the reaction of oxygen with other elements. In fire science, oxides can provide clues about combustion processes and the materials involved in a fire.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Oxygen
hasDefinedTerm.description: A gas that supports combustion and is a crucial component of the fire triangle (heat, fuel, and oxygen). The presence of sufficient oxygen is necessary for a fire to ignite and continue burning.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Oxygen Deficiency
hasDefinedTerm.description: A condition where the concentration of oxygen in the air is too low to sustain life. In fire scenarios, oxygen deficiency can result from rapid combustion and can be hazardous to individuals in the affected area.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Oxygen Sensors
hasDefinedTerm.description: Devices used to measure the concentration of oxygen in an environment. In firefighting and fire investigations, oxygen sensors help assess whether a space is safe for entry and whether fire conditions may change.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Ozone
hasDefinedTerm.description: A form of oxygen (O3) that can form during electrical arcing or lightning strikes. Ozone has a distinct smell and may be present in fire scenes where electrical activity played a role.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Ozonic
hasDefinedTerm.description: Pertaining to or having the properties of ozone. The term can be used in the context of fire scenes involving electrical arcing or reactions that produce ozone as a byproduct.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Pack Test
hasDefinedTerm.description: A physical fitness test used to evaluate the capability of wildland firefighters. The test simulates the physical demands of firefighting to ensure that personnel are prepared for the strenuous tasks required in wildfire response.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Paracargo
hasDefinedTerm.description: Supplies or equipment delivered by parachute, typically during wildfire operations to provide resources to firefighters working in remote areas. Paracargo drops can include food, water, tools, and other essentials.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Passive Fire Protection System
hasDefinedTerm.description: Fire safety features that do not require activation and work to prevent the spread of fire and smoke, such as fire-resistant walls, doors, and firestops. These systems help maintain structural integrity and allow safe evacuation.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Patterns of Spread
hasDefinedTerm.description: The observable paths and characteristics of how a fire has moved through an area. These patterns help fire investigators determine the origin and behavior of the fire.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Peak Fire Season
hasDefinedTerm.description: The time of year when fire activity is at its highest due to conditions like dry weather, high temperatures, and wind. Knowing the peak fire season is essential for preparedness and resource planning.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Personnel Protective Equipment (PPE)
hasDefinedTerm.description: Gear worn by firefighters and emergency responders to protect them from heat, flames, smoke, and other hazards. PPE includes helmets, gloves, fire-resistant clothing, and breathing apparatus.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Pilot Light
hasDefinedTerm.description: A small, continuous flame used to ignite gas in appliances such as stoves and water heaters. Malfunctioning pilot lights can lead to unintentional gas leaks and fire hazards.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Piloted Ignition Temperature
hasDefinedTerm.description: The minimum temperature at which a material will ignite when an external ignition source, such as a spark or flame, is present. This temperature is lower than the auto-ignition temperature.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Pipe Heat Sheild
hasDefinedTerm.description: A protective barrier designed to prevent heat transfer from a hot pipe to surrounding materials, reducing the risk of fire. Pipe heat shields are commonly used in industrial and residential settings.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Plastic
hasDefinedTerm.description: A synthetic or semi-synthetic material made from polymers that can ignite and burn at varying temperatures. Plastics can produce toxic fumes and contribute to the spread of fire.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Plug Fuses
hasDefinedTerm.description: Electrical safety devices that protect circuits by breaking the connection when current exceeds safe levels. Faulty or incorrect use of plug fuses can result in electrical fires.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Plume
hasDefinedTerm.description: The column of smoke, gas, and particles rising from a fire or explosion. The behavior of a plume, including its height and spread, can provide insights into the intensity and direction of a fire.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Point of Origin
hasDefinedTerm.description: The specific location where a fire started. Identifying the point of origin is crucial for fire investigations as it helps determine the ignition source and cause of the fire.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Post-Crash Fire
hasDefinedTerm.description: A fire that occurs after a vehicle collision or crash, often due to fuel leakage, damaged electrical systems, or other factors. Post-crash fires can be especially dangerous for occupants and first responders.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Post-Fire Analysis
hasDefinedTerm.description: The detailed examination of a fire scene after the fire has been extinguished. This analysis includes collecting evidence, documenting damage, and assessing burn patterns to determine the fire’s origin and cause.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Post-Fire Inspection
hasDefinedTerm.description: A formal review of a building or area following a fire to assess damage, ensure safety, and evaluate structural integrity. Inspections are necessary to determine the next steps for repair, restoration, or demolition.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Post-Fire Reconstruction
hasDefinedTerm.description: The process of rebuilding or repairing structures that have been damaged or destroyed by fire. This may involve replacing fire-damaged materials with fire-resistant alternatives and updating fire safety systems.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Power
hasDefinedTerm.description: The rate at which energy is transferred or used, commonly measured in watts or kilowatts. In fire investigations, power analysis can help determine whether electrical faults contributed to ignition.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Premixed Flame
hasDefinedTerm.description: A flame that occurs when fuel and oxidizer are mixed before ignition, producing a more controlled and even burn. Premixed flames are common in gas appliances and laboratory burners.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Preparedness
hasDefinedTerm.description: The state of being ready to respond effectively to a fire or emergency. Preparedness includes having fire safety plans, training personnel, and maintaining equipment to handle fire incidents promptly.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Prescribed Burning/Fire
hasDefinedTerm.description: A planned fire intentionally ignited under controlled conditions to reduce fuel load, manage ecosystems, and decrease the risk of larger, uncontrolled wildfires.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Prescribed Fire Plan (Burn Plan)
hasDefinedTerm.description: A detailed document outlining the objectives, conditions, and safety measures for conducting a prescribed burn. Burn plans ensure that prescribed fires are carried out safely and effectively.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Preservation
hasDefinedTerm.description: The act of protecting and maintaining evidence or a scene from tampering or degradation. Preservation is crucial in fire investigations to ensure accurate analysis and documentation.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Pressure, Explosives
hasDefinedTerm.description: The force exerted by expanding gases produced during an explosion. Understanding explosive pressure helps assess the impact and damage caused by explosive-related fire incidents.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Prevention
hasDefinedTerm.description: Actions taken to avoid fire ignition and reduce the risk of fire incidents. Prevention includes fire safety education, regular maintenance, and adherence to fire codes and regulations.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Print Data
hasDefinedTerm.description: Information or records captured in printed format, such as floor plans, maintenance logs, and emergency response documents. Print data can be valuable for fire investigations and planning.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Production Equipment Maintenance
hasDefinedTerm.description: The routine servicing and inspection of equipment used in industrial production to ensure safety and proper function. Poor maintenance can lead to mechanical failures that may cause fires.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Production Line Fire
hasDefinedTerm.description: A fire that occurs in the assembly line or manufacturing area of a facility. These fires may be fueled by machinery, flammable materials, or industrial chemicals.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Products of Combustion
hasDefinedTerm.description: Substances produced when a material burns, including gases, heat, light, smoke, and particulate matter. Understanding combustion products is important for assessing fire hazards and toxic exposure risks.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Project Fire
hasDefinedTerm.description: A large, complex fire that requires extensive coordination, multiple resources, and long-term management efforts. Project fires often span large geographic areas and pose significant challenges to firefighting operations.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Proof of Loss
hasDefinedTerm.description: A formal document submitted to an insurance company that details the loss or damage claimed by the policyholder, such as after a fire incident. This document is required for the claims process and must include supporting evidence.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Property Insurance Loss Register (PILR)
hasDefinedTerm.description: A centralized database used by insurance companies to track claims made by policyholders. The PILR helps insurers assess risk and detect potential fraud, including claims related to fire damage.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Propulsion System Fire
hasDefinedTerm.description: A fire that occurs in the propulsion system of a vehicle, such as an engine or motor. These fires can result from fuel leaks, electrical malfunctions, or overheating and pose significant risks to passengers and responders.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Protection Area
hasDefinedTerm.description: A designated region where specific fire management and protective measures are implemented to prevent and control fires. Protection areas are often established to safeguard natural resources, structures, and communities.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Protocol
hasDefinedTerm.description: A set of procedures or guidelines followed during fire response, investigation, or management. Protocols ensure that all actions are conducted systematically and in accordance with best practices for safety and effectiveness.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Proximate Cause
hasDefinedTerm.description: The primary or immediate reason for the ignition of a fire, which directly leads to its occurrence. Identifying the proximate cause is crucial in fire investigations to determine accountability and liability.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Pugilisitc Attitude (posture)
hasDefinedTerm.description: The position that a body can take during exposure to intense heat, characterized by flexed limbs due to muscle contractions. This posture can provide clues about the circumstances and intensity of a fire in investigations involving fatalities.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Pulaski
hasDefinedTerm.description: A hand tool with a combination axe and adze head, used by wildland firefighters for digging fire lines and clearing vegetation. The Pulaski is essential for creating barriers to control and contain wildfires.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Pulled Bulb
hasDefinedTerm.description: A lightbulb that has been deformed or stretched due to exposure to high heat. The appearance of a pulled bulb can help fire investigators determine the heat direction and intensity at a fire scene.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Pyrolysate
hasDefinedTerm.description: A byproduct produced during the thermal decomposition of materials in the absence of oxygen. Pyrolysates can contribute to flammable gas mixtures that lead to fire spread or explosions.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Pyrolysis
hasDefinedTerm.description: The chemical decomposition of materials due to heat in the absence of oxygen, which produces gases that can ignite and sustain a fire. Pyrolysis is a key process in understanding how fires start and develop.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Pyromania
hasDefinedTerm.description: A psychological condition characterized by an uncontrollable urge to set fires for pleasure or relief from tension. Pyromania is a recognized mental disorder and is often considered in cases of arson.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Pyrophoric Material
hasDefinedTerm.description: A substance that can spontaneously ignite when exposed to air due to its highly reactive nature. Examples include certain metals and chemical compounds used in industry.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Radiant Burn
hasDefinedTerm.description: A burn injury caused by exposure to intense radiant heat from a fire or hot object without direct contact. Radiant burns can occur at significant distances from the heat source.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Radiant Heat
hasDefinedTerm.description: Heat energy that is transferred through electromagnetic waves from a hot surface or flame to surrounding objects. Radiant heat can ignite nearby flammable materials and cause severe damage.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Radiant Heat Flux
hasDefinedTerm.description: The rate of heat energy emitted per unit area from a radiating source. High radiant heat flux can lead to ignition of flammable materials and contribute to fire spread.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Radiation
hasDefinedTerm.description: The transfer of heat energy through electromagnetic waves without the need for direct contact. Radiation is one of the primary ways fires spread heat to surrounding objects and materials.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Rapid Charging
hasDefinedTerm.description: The process of quickly recharging batteries at a high current, which can lead to overheating if not properly managed. Rapid charging poses a fire risk, especially with lithium-ion batteries.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Rappeling
hasDefinedTerm.description: A technique used by firefighters to descend steep or vertical surfaces with the aid of ropes and harnesses. Rappelling is often employed in rugged terrain to access areas affected by wildfires.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Rate of Spread
hasDefinedTerm.description: The speed at which a fire moves across a surface or through vegetation, typically measured in chains or meters per hour. The rate of spread helps fire managers assess fire behavior and develop suppression tactics.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Reburn
hasDefinedTerm.description: The process where a previously burned area reignites and burns again, often due to remaining fuel that was not consumed during the initial fire. Reburns can occur when conditions become favorable for ignition.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Red Card
hasDefinedTerm.description: A certification card issued to wildland firefighters indicating that they have met the training and physical fitness requirements to engage in firefighting activities. The Red Card ensures that personnel are qualified for wildfire assignments.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Red Flag Warning
hasDefinedTerm.description: A weather alert issued by meteorological agencies when conditions such as high winds, low humidity, and dry fuels create a high potential for rapid fire spread. Red flag warnings help fire managers and the public prepare for increased fire risk.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Red Zone
hasDefinedTerm.description: Areas identified as high risk for wildfire due to factors like dense vegetation, dry conditions, and proximity to populated areas. These zones require heightened fire prevention and response efforts.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Rehabilitation
hasDefinedTerm.description: The process of restoring land and infrastructure after a fire has been contained. Rehabilitation efforts include stabilizing soil, replanting vegetation, and repairing damage to minimize environmental and structural impacts.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Rekindle
hasDefinedTerm.description: The re-ignition of a fire that was previously extinguished, often due to smoldering embers or hotspots that were not completely suppressed. Preventing rekindles is a key focus during the overhaul phase of firefighting.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Relative Humidity
hasDefinedTerm.description: The amount of moisture in the air relative to the maximum amount of moisture the air can hold at a given temperature. Low relative humidity can increase fire risk by drying out fuels and making them more flammable.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Remote Automatic Weather Station (RAWS)
hasDefinedTerm.description: A weather monitoring station that provides real-time data on temperature, humidity, wind speed, and other factors that influence fire behavior. RAWS units are critical for fire prediction and management.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Rescue and Firefighting Craft
hasDefinedTerm.description: Specialized boats and vessels equipped for fire suppression and rescue operations on water. These craft are used to combat fires on ships, docks, and waterfront properties.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Resource Management Plan (RMP)
hasDefinedTerm.description: A strategic document that outlines the use and conservation of natural resources, including fire management practices. RMPs help land managers balance environmental health with fire risk reduction.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Resource Order
hasDefinedTerm.description: A formal request for specific resources, such as equipment, personnel, or aircraft, during a fire response. Resource orders ensure that firefighting efforts are well-supported and coordinated.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Resources
hasDefinedTerm.description: The personnel, equipment, and tools used in firefighting operations. Effective use of resources is essential for successful fire suppression and control.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Responsibility
hasDefinedTerm.description: The obligation to take preventive measures and respond to fire incidents in accordance with established guidelines. Responsibility can apply to individuals, organizations, or governing bodies in fire management.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Retardant
hasDefinedTerm.description: A chemical substance applied to vegetation or structures to slow the spread of fire. Fire retardants are used in aerial firefighting operations and ground-based fire prevention strategies.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Right of Entry
hasDefinedTerm.description: The legal authorization for fire investigators, firefighters, or emergency personnel to enter a property to suppress a fire, conduct an investigation, or ensure safety compliance.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Risk
hasDefinedTerm.description: The likelihood of a fire occurring and the potential consequences associated with it. Risk assessment helps fire management teams develop strategies to reduce and manage fire hazards.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Risk Management
hasDefinedTerm.description: The process of identifying, assessing, and mitigating risks associated with fire incidents. Risk management strategies aim to minimize damage and enhance safety in communities and work environments.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Rollover
hasDefinedTerm.description: The condition where hot gases and flames spread across a ceiling and roll out from the top of a compartment. Rollover is a precursor to flashover and indicates rapidly worsening fire conditions.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Run (of a fire)
hasDefinedTerm.description: A period when a fire spreads rapidly over a significant distance due to favorable conditions such as wind and fuel availability. Runs can lead to sudden increases in fire size and intensity.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Running
hasDefinedTerm.description: The movement of a fire in a continuous, fast-paced manner over a landscape. Running fires are difficult to control and can cover large areas quickly, posing significant threats to property and safety.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Rural Fire District
hasDefinedTerm.description: A designated area managed by a local fire department responsible for providing fire protection services to rural communities. These districts often rely on volunteer firefighters and may face unique challenges due to limited resources.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Rural Fire Protection
hasDefinedTerm.description: Fire prevention and suppression services provided to rural areas, often managed by volunteer fire departments or local fire districts. These services include wildfire response, structural fire protection, and public education.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Sabotage
hasDefinedTerm.description: The deliberate act of damaging or interfering with equipment or processes to cause harm or disrupt operations. In fire investigations, sabotage may be considered if there is evidence of intentional tampering that led to a fire.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Saddle Burn
hasDefinedTerm.description: A burn pattern that forms on a ridge or saddle-shaped terrain, indicating how a fire moved over the topography. Saddle burns help investigators understand fire behavior in hilly or mountainous regions.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Safety Cutoff Switch
hasDefinedTerm.description: A switch designed to shut off power or fuel supply in an emergency to prevent overheating and reduce fire risk. Safety cutoff switches are commonly found in electrical and gas-powered equipment.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Safety Inspection
hasDefinedTerm.description: A thorough examination of buildings, equipment, or systems to identify potential fire hazards and ensure compliance with fire codes and safety standards. Safety inspections help prevent fires and improve overall safety.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Safety Inspections
hasDefinedTerm.description: Regular or periodic assessments conducted to identify and mitigate fire risks in facilities or properties. These inspections ensure that fire prevention measures and safety protocols are in place and functioning properly.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Safety Protocol
hasDefinedTerm.description: A set of procedures and practices established to protect individuals and property from fire hazards. Safety protocols are implemented in workplaces, residential areas, and during fire response operations to reduce risk and enhance safety.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Safety Protocols
hasDefinedTerm.description: Comprehensive guidelines followed by individuals or organizations to prevent fire incidents and ensure the safety of personnel. Safety protocols include evacuation plans, fire drills, and proper handling of flammable materials.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Safety Training
hasDefinedTerm.description: Instruction and practice provided to individuals to help them understand fire safety principles, use firefighting equipment, and respond effectively in emergencies. Safety training is essential for both firefighters and the general public.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Safety Zone
hasDefinedTerm.description: A designated area where firefighters and personnel can seek refuge from a fire without the risk of injury or death. Safety zones are critical for ensuring the well-being of firefighting teams during wildfire operations.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Salvor
hasDefinedTerm.description: A person or company involved in the recovery and preservation of property following a fire or disaster. Salvors may work with insurance companies to assess damage and determine the salvageable value of assets.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Scene
hasDefinedTerm.description: The location where a fire incident has occurred, which becomes the focus of investigation and response efforts. The scene is documented and analyzed to gather evidence, determine the cause, and assess damage.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Scene Documentation
hasDefinedTerm.description: The process of recording details and observations at a fire scene through photographs, sketches, and written reports. Documentation is essential for investigations, insurance claims, and legal proceedings.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Scene Preservation
hasDefinedTerm.description: The practice of protecting a fire scene from contamination, tampering, or destruction to ensure the integrity of evidence for investigation purposes. Proper scene preservation is vital for accurate fire analysis.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Scent Discrimination
hasDefinedTerm.description: The ability of trained canines to differentiate between various scents at a fire scene, particularly to detect accelerants or specific chemicals. This skill is valuable in arson investigations.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Scientific Method
hasDefinedTerm.description: A systematic approach used in fire investigations to collect data, form hypotheses, conduct experiments, and draw conclusions. The scientific method ensures that findings are objective and evidence-based.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Scratch Line
hasDefinedTerm.description: A shallow, quickly constructed firebreak made by removing vegetation and debris to slow the advance of a fire. Scratch lines are often created by hand crews as an initial effort to control fire spread.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Search Pattern
hasDefinedTerm.description: A systematic approach used by investigators to thoroughly examine a fire scene for evidence. Common search patterns include grid, spiral, and strip methods to ensure no area is overlooked.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Seat of Explosion
hasDefinedTerm.description: The exact location where an explosion originates, determined by analyzing blast damage, debris patterns, and other evidence. Identifying the seat of an explosion is crucial for understanding the cause and potential accelerants involved.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Seat Upholstery Burn
hasDefinedTerm.description: The damage to the upholstery of seats caused by fire or heat exposure. The pattern and extent of these burns can help fire investigators understand fire behavior, intensity, and the direction of flames in vehicle or structural fires.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Seated Explosion
hasDefinedTerm.description: An explosion that has a defined point of origin and leaves evidence of a blast seat. This type of explosion is often contrasted with diffuse explosions, which do not have a clearly defined source.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Secondary Explosion
hasDefinedTerm.description: An additional explosion that occurs after an initial explosion, often due to the ignition of unburned fuel or gases released in the first event. Secondary explosions can cause significant additional damage and pose dangers to responders.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Self-Extinguishing Materials
hasDefinedTerm.description: Materials that are capable of stopping combustion on their own once the heat source is removed. These materials help prevent the spread of fire and are used in fire-resistant construction and products.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Self-Heating
hasDefinedTerm.description: The process by which certain materials generate heat internally due to chemical reactions, oxidation, or biological activity. If not properly managed, self-heating can lead to spontaneous ignition.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Self-Ignition
hasDefinedTerm.description: The spontaneous ignition of a material without an external flame or spark, usually due to heat buildup from internal chemical reactions or friction. Self-ignition poses risks in environments with oily rags, compost, or certain chemicals.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Self-Ignition Temperature
hasDefinedTerm.description: The lowest temperature at which a material will ignite spontaneously without an external ignition source. Understanding this temperature is key for fire prevention and handling flammable materials.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Self-Incrimination
hasDefinedTerm.description: The act of implicating oneself in a crime or admitting to actions that may result in legal consequences. In fire investigations, individuals may avoid self-incrimination by exercising their legal rights during questioning.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Seperator Failure
hasDefinedTerm.description: The malfunction of a battery or chemical separator that prevents contact between components such as electrodes. Separator failures can lead to short circuits and potential fires or explosions in battery systems.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Server Arc
hasDefinedTerm.description: An electrical discharge that occurs when a high-voltage connection is interrupted, creating a spark or arc. Server arcs can cause heat buildup and pose fire hazards in electrical systems.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Severity Funding
hasDefinedTerm.description: Financial resources allocated to address extreme fire conditions, often used for additional personnel, equipment, or emergency response activities. Severity funding supports proactive measures during peak fire seasons.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Short Circuit
hasDefinedTerm.description: An unintended path of electrical current that bypasses the normal circuit, causing a surge in current flow. Short circuits can generate heat, leading to electrical fires and damage to connected devices.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Single Resource
hasDefinedTerm.description: An individual piece of equipment or person assigned to a firefighting task, such as an engine or a firefighter. Single resources are deployed to specific tasks or areas as part of larger fire response operations.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Site
hasDefinedTerm.description: The location where a fire incident has occurred or is being investigated. The site may be a structure, vehicle, or open area and is crucial for evidence collection and analysis.

hasDefinedTerm.name: SIU
hasDefinedTerm.description: Special Investigations Unit, a department within an insurance company or law enforcement agency that investigates suspicious claims or potential fraud. SIUs often collaborate with fire investigators in cases of suspected arson.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Size-up
hasDefinedTerm.description: The initial assessment conducted by first responders or fire commanders to evaluate the situation, identify potential hazards, and plan an effective response. Size-up is essential for determining strategies and allocating resources during a fire incident.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Slash
hasDefinedTerm.description: Debris from forestry operations, including branches, twigs, and cut vegetation, which can contribute to fire risk if not properly managed. Slash is often reduced or removed to prevent wildfires.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Sleeving
hasDefinedTerm.description: The protective covering applied to electrical wires and cables to insulate them and prevent heat transfer. Damaged or inadequate sleeving can increase the risk of electrical fires.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Sling Load
hasDefinedTerm.description: Cargo carried beneath a helicopter for delivery to remote or hard-to-reach fire locations. Sling loads may include firefighting supplies, water, or equipment and play a vital role in wildfire response.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Slope
hasDefinedTerm.description: The angle or gradient of the land, which affects fire behavior and spread. Fires tend to move more rapidly uphill due to the preheating of vegetation above the fire.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Slop-over
hasDefinedTerm.description: The situation when a fire crosses a control line or firebreak, often due to wind, ember spotting, or changes in fire behavior. Slop-overs require immediate attention to prevent further spread.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Smoke
hasDefinedTerm.description: A mixture of gases, vapor, and particulate matter produced by the combustion of materials. Smoke can contain toxic compounds and reduce visibility, posing health risks and challenges for firefighting efforts.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Smoke Condensate
hasDefinedTerm.description: The liquid or solid residue that forms when smoke cools and settles on surfaces. Analyzing smoke condensate can help fire investigators determine fire origin and the types of materials burned.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Smoke Damage
hasDefinedTerm.description: The physical harm caused to structures, furniture, or belongings by smoke from a fire. This damage can include discoloration, odor, and corrosive effects on surfaces and electronics.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Smoke Explosion
hasDefinedTerm.description: Also known as a backdraft, this occurs when a fire smolders in an enclosed space, depleting oxygen and accumulating flammable gases. When oxygen is introduced, these gases ignite explosively.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Smoke Inhalation
hasDefinedTerm.description: The intake of smoke and combustion byproducts into the respiratory system, which can lead to serious health issues or death. Smoke inhalation is a common cause of fire-related fatalities.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Smoke Jumper
hasDefinedTerm.description: A specially trained firefighter who parachutes into remote areas to combat wildfires. Smoke jumpers are deployed for rapid response to fires in locations inaccessible by traditional ground vehicles.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Smoke Management
hasDefinedTerm.description: The practice of controlling and dispersing smoke from fires to minimize its impact on air quality and visibility. Techniques include controlled burns, timing operations, and using natural wind patterns to direct smoke away from populated areas.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Smoke Patterns
hasDefinedTerm.description: The shapes and trails left by smoke deposits on surfaces, which can help fire investigators understand fire movement and ventilation conditions within a structure.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Smoke Production
hasDefinedTerm.description: The process by which smoke is generated during combustion. Smoke production varies based on fuel type, temperature, and fire conditions.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Smoke Staining
hasDefinedTerm.description: The discoloration of surfaces caused by smoke deposits. Smoke staining can be used to identify fire paths and areas of higher heat exposure during an investigation.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Smoke Ventilation
hasDefinedTerm.description: The controlled removal of smoke from a building or structure to improve visibility and reduce heat buildup during a fire. Smoke ventilation can be natural, mechanical, or performed by firefighters using equipment like fans and exhaust vents.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Smoldering
hasDefinedTerm.description: A type of combustion that occurs at a low temperature and without visible flames, producing smoke and heat. Smoldering fires can persist for long periods and reignite if exposed to oxygen or a heat source.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Smoldering Fire
hasDefinedTerm.description: A fire that burns slowly with little flame and produces large amounts of smoke. Smoldering fires are common in dense fuels like peat or insulation and can be difficult to fully extinguish.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Snag
hasDefinedTerm.description: A dead or dying tree that is still standing, which can become a fire hazard due to its dry and combustible nature. Snags can fall during a fire, posing risks to firefighters and property.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Solid-State Batteries
hasDefinedTerm.description: A type of battery that uses solid electrolytes instead of liquid or gel-based ones. While solid-state batteries are generally safer and less prone to fire, improper handling or damage can still result in combustion.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Soluble
hasDefinedTerm.description: The property of a substance that allows it to dissolve in a solvent, such as water or alcohol. Understanding solubility is important for selecting fire suppression agents and analyzing fire debris.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Soot
hasDefinedTerm.description: Black, carbon-based particulate matter produced during incomplete combustion. Soot can settle on surfaces, contributing to smoke damage and posing health risks if inhaled.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Spalling
hasDefinedTerm.description: The flaking or breaking away of a material's surface due to intense heat exposure. Spalling is commonly observed in concrete or masonry during fires and can provide clues about the heat intensity and duration at a fire scene.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Spark
hasDefinedTerm.description: A small particle of burning material or an electrical discharge that can ignite flammable substances. Sparks are a common source of fire ignition in welding, grinding, and electrical work.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Specific Gravity
hasDefinedTerm.description: The ratio of the density of a substance to the density of water. Specific gravity can be used to understand the behavior of liquid fuels and their interaction with water during fire suppression.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Specific Heat
hasDefinedTerm.description: The amount of heat energy required to raise the temperature of a unit mass of a substance by one degree Celsius. In fire science, understanding specific heat helps assess how materials absorb and transfer heat during a fire.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Specific Origin Area
hasDefinedTerm.description: The focused location within the general origin area where the fire first ignited. Identifying the specific origin area is crucial for pinpointing ignition sources and determining the cause of a fire.
